title: mum accused parking six hours
story: Mum accused of parking for six hours after buying coffees at McDonalds drive-thruTracy Stephenson had stopped to buy a latte and later received a fine from parking firm UK Parking Control, who said her van was stopped outside for five hours and  minutesUKPC says her van was outside for nearly six hours Image: TeessideliveByPoppy KennedyAntony ThrowerNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A mum faces a hefty fine after a firm claimed s he was parked outside a McDonald’s restaurant for nearly six hours when she popped in for a quick coffee. Tracy Stephenson had stopped to buy two lattes at the drive-thru before dropping her partner off at work on February .A week later her partner received a £ fine in the post from UK Parking Controlwho claimed the van was outside for five hours and  minutes, Teesside Live reports. Tracy, , has appealed the fine, which can be halvedpaid quickly, but fears she does not have proof to convince them of her innocence. She said: For them to come out with this five hours and  minutes - itaposs absolutely ridiculous. I knew Iaposd come back to Darlington because I had appointments and was making phone calls. I doubt they havenapost even looked in the time frame of the  possibly  minutes after we were pictured going in to seewe had left. Have you been been given a ticket like Tracy  Email webnews@mirror  If I had done it I would have just owned up to it and paid the fine and sulked, but the fact I definitely was not there for that duration is just beggaraposs belief. I donapost know what  I can do, Iaposm just tearing my hair out. “Itaposs £ I havenapost got, Iaposm a single mum - my partner doesnapost live with me - and I canapost afford it and I refuse to pay it when I havenapost done anything wrong.” Having posted about her experience on social media someone replied she may have fallen foul of the “double dip” camera fault, where automatic number plate recognition cameras pick up the first entrance and second exit which are often hours apart. Although it is clear she is in the van on the first image, the number plate on the rear of the vehicle on the exit image, taken almost six hours later, is hazy and potentially a dferent vehicle. She fears her last hope to get proof she was parked on her drive in Darlington during the time through phone records. Tracy added: “They have dismissed the fact that Iaposve said I was not there. They havenapost investigated it any further on their side and theyaposre just wanting me to pay up. I would never use that drive-thru again and Iaposd be reluctant to use car parks operated by UKPC now.Iaposd never heard of the term double-dip before but Iaposd posted on Facebook and others whoaposve had similar things happen to them said itaposs when you go twice in the same day and the camera picks up your first entrance and last exit.I canapost remember ever going twice in one day. On the images, the first image is clearly my partner and I in the van and the number plate is as clear as day. The second one, the number plate is a bit hazy. You can make out the end of it but the start isnapost clear and could look like dferent letters and numbers. “Itaposs daylight robbery.” UKPC has been approached for comment. news uk-news mums-hysterical-screams-pet-dog-"Liverpool: Police confirm name of toddler attacked by dogByAlahna KindredNews ReporterHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments A mum was heard screaming hysterically as her new pet dog mauled her baby to death.Bella-Rae Birch was just -months-old when she was attacked in her home in St Helens, Merseyside yesterday.Neighbour Jordan, who lives on a nearby road to the road from the family, said the babyaposs devastated mother Treysharn Bates was crying hysterically outside the house moments after yesterday’s horror attack. Jordan, who is hoping to go to university in September to train to be a paramedic, ran over to help when she heard screaming. She said: I gave CPR to the baby. My head is a mess. I heard them screaming for help and I ran over. The parents were hysterical. Iaposve lived here for eight years but Iaposve never spoken to them before.Have you been impacted by this incident  Email webnews@mirrorPolice were called at around .pm following reports that a child had been attacked by a dog at an address in Blackbrook, St Helens. Emergency services attended and Bella-Rae was taken to hospital where she sadly died as a result of her injuries. The dog was handed over to the police at the address and has been humanely destroyed. Shocked residents of Bidston Avenue in the town spoke of their utter devastation after the horric incident.Locals in the “quiet” road fought back tears as they fondly remembered watching the tot playing with her brother. Neighbour Joanne Matthews, , said: She was such a beautul little girl, toddling about. Iaposd see the family in passing, just to say hello, and they were always very pleasant. One resident, who did not wish to be named, said: “They were a lovely family, and it’s just devastating what has happened. “The dog had a stocky build, it was a Staffordshire terrier or Pitbull, and it was fully grown. There was only one.  “It’s devastating. This is a normal quiet street, and the children would play in the street. The little girl, a toddler, was always about. It’s a shame I won’t be able to see that again. Mourners gathered to lay flowers at the house, which was taped off this morning as police officers stood guard. Neighbours said that the family of four had lived at the house for around three years but had only recently purchased the dog. Another neighbour, who only wanted to provide his first name, David, said: There were absolutely loads of police officers, there must have been about  police cars and ambulances.  The square was absolutely swarming with them, Iaposve never seen so many police in my le. I was just in shock when I heard a baby had been attacked by a dog. I believe the dog was tranquilised in the house with a dart gun. Other neighbours reported seeing the animal brought out with a metal collar and rod by police officers. Speaking this morning, Superintendant Steve Brizell said: We were called by the family of a  month old girl Bella-Rae Birch, Bella Rae has lost her le in the most unimaginably terrible circumstances and our thoughts are first and foremost with the family and the wider community at this time.  Our specialist family liaison officers are providing the family of Bella-Rae with support and officers will remain in the area in the coming days to provide further support and reassurance for the wider community. Detective Inspector Lisa Milligan said yesterday: This is a tragic incident and our thoughts are with the child’s family at this devastating time. The little girl’s parents and wider family are absolutely devastated and our specialist Family Liaison Officers are providing them with support at this horrendous time. Whilst we are in the very early stages of the investigation into this extremely tragic incident we can confirm that the dog was only bought by the family a week ago and officers are working to identy the previous owners of the dog concerned and establish its history. Our officers will remain on Bidston Avenue this evening and in the coming days to provide reassurance to the local community and we will work tirelessly to establish the full circumstances. “If you were in the Bidston Avenue area this afternoon and witnessed anything, or have any information about the dog in question then please come forward speak to one of our officers. Our officers take the issue of dangerous dogs very seriously. Over the past years we have worked proactively with the five local authorities in Merseyside to ensure prohibited dogs are taken off the streets.“ The dog will be subject to further forensic examinations to determine the breed of dog and whether it is or isn’t a legal breed, the police have said. Officers remain at the scene this evening to examine CCTV, speak to witnesses and go door-to-door.Anyone with any information is asked to contact us via the social media desk @MerPolCC or aposMerseyside Police Contact Centreapos on Facebook, with reference . Alternatively, you can call the independent charity @CrimestoppersUK anonymously, on    or by visiting here.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Merseyside PoliceCCTVBabiesHospitalsCCTV footagePolice carDangerous dogsAnimals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: starving brits asking gps prescribe
story: Starving Brits asking GPs to prescribe nutritional shakes amid cost of living crisis"Working families", opposed to people receiving benefits, have been turning up at a GP practice in Bolton asking for help with food costs and nutritional milkshake prescriptions because they cant afford to eat as living costs continue to spike, according to Dr Helen WallDr Helen Wall says shes had working families, opposed to people receiving benefits, turning up at her practice who arent eating at allByHelena VestyRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsStarving Brits have been turning up at GP surgeries asking doctors to prescribe nutritional shakes and help with food shopping because they canapost afford to eat.Dr Helen Wall says the working families she sees are feeling humiliated and embarrassed for seeking help with their financial struggles.Dr Wall - who says sheaposs no stranger to patients struggling financially - believes the last couple of weeks has felt dferent because people sheaposs received struggling patients who wouldnapost have been impacted before.Many come to her with concerns that they canapost pay their bills, not managing to pay them at all, or they tell her they canapost do everyday things like getting a food shop, she tells Manchester Evening News.“It’s not just people who are on benefits, it’s working people, she says.It’s people who are having to put fuel in their car to go to work, but are not on very highly paid jobs. Dr Well adds: I have started to see patients who aren’t eating, or aren’t eating well.Living on toast, living on fizzy, sugary drinks, and go all day on that.  Patients are contacting us desperate for help to buy food, even be prescribed nutritional shakes as [theyaposre] feeling so weak having paid their energy bills, [paid for] petrol to get to work, increasing costs [mean they are] unable to eat. We would never prescribe nutritional supplements, itaposs not the answer to the problem and itaposs not the right thing to do.But people have asked me and thataposs a really upsetting thing to hear.Someone has to be in a really dficult place to get to that point. The medicaposs concerns come as energy bills are set to go up by £ per year for around  million people from the start of April.People are also bracing themselves for rising inflation and tax hikes, which will a further rise in October as well. Making matters worse, the cost of petrol is also skyrocketing as the Russia-Ukraine war rages on, with sanctions also impacting the UKaposs finances, the Chancellor warned ahead of his Spring Statement on Wednesday.Controversy surrounding Rishi Sunakaposs announcement last month that million households will get a £ aposrebateapos on their energy bills from October, as he shared that this money will be clawed back by hiking bills by £ per year over five years from . As many as one in four patients are raising anxieties around the cost of living to the Bolton GP, she estimates, out of approximately  per day.All of her practice colleagues are seeing similar patterns.  She added: Itaposs become a routine question now when I see people with health issues that might be impacted by poor nutrition or not eating.Previously it was aposare you managing to eat aposAs in aposhave you lost your appetite apos Now itaposs aposare you physically managing to get food to eat apos The weight of financial worries can have a devastating impact - only adding to the fatigue of a population already aposbattered mentally and financiallyapos as it continues to deal with a now two-year-long pandemic, according to the GP. She said: What has struck me is that some of the patients Iaposve spoken to in the past week or two, itaposs the embarrassment and humiliation that people feel.Theyaposre telling the GP because some of them havenapost told their friends that they canapost afford to eat because they donapost want that humiliation.  Your friend or your health care specialist might not be able to fix that for you instantly, but it will really help your mental healthyou feel like you can share it. While fellow GP, Dr Murugesan Raja, has not yet had such drastic requests from his patients, he is worried by the rise in the numbers heaposs aware of using food banks.Food poverty was a big issue already, said the Fallowfield -based doctor. Likewise, Dr Faisal Bhutta, a GP in Hyde, says he too is aware that the practiceaposs local food bank has been aposvery busyapos lately.The Bolton GP says she is looking for more ways they can help with food poverty, in anticipation that the problem will only grow, and voluntary groups or charities may be overwhelmed by whataposs coming.  Dr Wall hopes for the destigmatisation of financial struggles, so people feel comfortable to put their hands up and say I need help, I canapost survive like this and direct Government intervention, like a cap on expanding living costs. In response to the MENaposs questions about those on the breadline going to their GP for urgent help, a government spokesperson said: “We recognise the pressures people are facing with the cost of living, which is why we’re providing support worth £billion this financial year and next to help. This includes putting an average of £, more per year into the pockets of working families via changes to Universal Credit, freezing fuel duties to keep costs down and helping households with their energy bills through our £.billion Energy Bills Rebate. “We’re also boosting the minimum wage by more than £, a year for full-time workers and our £million Household Support Fund is helping the most vulnerable with essential costs.” But in the short term, less nutritional food is often cheaper, Dr Wall points out.Andpeople arenapost getting their basic vitamins and minerals, it can lead to a host of further medical problems, such as delayed healing time, immune system decline and a higher risk of infection. Years down the line, that could spell upticks in diabetes, heart disease - and thataposs before mentioning mental health. People are saying things like aposI havenapost gotten right to be worried about this because it could be worse, we could be in a war situationapos, sighs Dr Wall.Thereaposs that guilt that things arenapost as bad as others have them. All of that is going impact on peopleaposs mental health.And itaposs a real concern that weaposre only at the edge of this, coming into it. We all know it’s probably going to get worse, not better unless something changes dramatically. title: student 19 who thought freshers
story: Student, , given devastating diagnosis after thinking she had freshers fluThe -year old put her persistent cough weight loss and a hard cm lump that appeared above her collarbone down to leading a typical student lestyle.Zara Barton said her skin started to become itchy last February but dismissed it as a stress rash from a bad break-up Image: Kennedy News and MediaByLiam Buckler:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA student who thought her cough and large lump below her neck was just freshers flu was stunned to discover she actually had blood cancer. Zara Barton, , said her skin started to become itchy last February but dismissed it as a stress rash from an aposupsetting break-upapos or from boozing too much and was prescribed creams and antihistamines by doctors. She put her persistent cough weight loss and a hard cm lump that appeared above her collarbone down to leading a apostypical student lestyleapos. However, after the hives on her body became aposunbearableapos the fashion marketing and branding student pressed for answers and was shocked to eventually be diagnosed with stage three Hodgkin Lymphoma last November. The student had her eggs collected to help preserve her fertility before she started chemotherapy in December, and now, halfway through her treatment, she received the good news last month that there were no signs of active cancer in her body. The -year old is passionate about raising awareness of the symptoms of Hodgkin Lymphoma and urges anyone who recognises the symptoms to visit a doctor - and to keep ingtheyaposre not taken seriously. Zara, of Solihull, West Midlands, said: I thinkpeople recognise the symptoms, donapost hesitate to go to the doctors, evenyou feel like it is nothing because I just assumed aposit was nothing to worry about.  Something like itching, I didnapost have a clue that that was a sign of blood cancer. Itaposs best to double-check and you can tell when somethingaposs not right, even at the very start when I was getting the itching I just thought aposthis isnapost me, this doesnapost feel right. So itaposs important to be persistentyou still feel like something is wrong. Iaposve had so many comments on my TikTok about people with similar experiences of going to the doctors and not really being listened to and I guess thataposs because weaposre young and they just think apostheyaposre fit and healthyapos. The -year old said that her itching started last February and she visited the doctor in May where she was prescribed medication, which she hoped would solve the issue. However, it got progressively worse to the point where sheaposd scratch her skin so much it would bruise. In addition, she experienced weight loss and lost around a stone - but thought it was due to eating less. Zara said: Iaposd itch, which would then come up in hives almost anywhere on my body - so my arms, legs, feet, anywhere really.  It would literally drive me mad. It would be hot and was really getting unbearable. It was really persistent and there was nothing I could do to stop it. I had creams that I would put on but I remember sometimes Iaposd lie there with cold flannels and a fan just to try and make it more bearable. I put the itching down to multiple things. I did go through a pretty upsetting breakup in Mayand during that time had a bad stress rash, so I thought maybe that had continued. I thought being at university with constant late nights, drinking regularly, probably not eating as well as I should - these were just lestyle things that made me think at the time aposokI was eating more healthily, getting more sleep, not going out as much then maybe this wouldnapost be happeningapos. The -year old had a aposreally reactive swollen glandapos on one side of her neck which would disappear and reappear again for months. But she thought this wasnapost a cause for concern, given sheaposd previously had swollen glands from having tonsillitis and was at university where she assumed sheaposd pick up colds and illnesses. Zara said: When I first noticed it [the lump], I wasnapost alarmed at all. It was during freshers so I thought maybe it was a bit of freshers flu and could just be a swollen gland. I also noticed I had a cough which never really went away. I thought it was freshers flu. My friends all had coughs at around the same time, it was nothing really dferent compared to the people around me.I put a lot of my symptoms down to student le, especially with not being at home. My mum and I were sayingI was at home maybe we would have picked it up sooner but because youaposre so on the go you kind of just brush these things off. It was a bit dficult to get seen by the doctors as well as they were mainly telephone consultations. Theyaposre symptoms that you can so easily put down to something  and I guess I thought they were all separate issues. Zara said that at the start of October she found another lump above her collar bone and ed to the doctors, who she claims wasnapost concerned. However, at the end of the month, she saw another doctor who ran several blood tests and referred her for an urgent ultrasound scan. On November th, the evening of her scan, Zara received her diagnosis. Zara said: The doctor obviously didnapost want to have to tell me this over the phone but Iaposd been so persistent on finding out I couldnapost wait until the next day. He was like aposhave you heard of Lymphoma apos and I was like aposno, what is it apos He was like aposoh, itaposs blood cancerapos. Obviously that was just a huge shock. I just didnapost know what to expect, what that meant and what I was about to go through.He was trying to explain the treatments I might have. Obviously we didnapost know everything about it yet and we still had to find out what type and stage. You think the worst I suppose. My scan results came back showing it was stage three. It came back and showed that it was all in my neck, chest and in my spleen. That was quite scary as well finding out that it had got to that point without me knowing because I felt so normal in myself otherwise. After she was told that there was a risk of becoming infertile after chemotherapy, the student had an operation to remove and freeze her eggs in December. Ten days later Zara started chemotherapy at Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Birmingham and has since had seven rounds with five more to go. She said that her itching stopped after her first session and has decided to take a year out of her studies, and will redo the year come September. Since her diagnosis, the teen who shares informative videos about the uncommon cancer that develops in the lymphatic system, said that the support sheaposd received from family, friends and even strangers has been amazing. Zara said: My diagnosis has affected my le a lot. I was living at university with my friends and literally felt the happiest Iaposd ever been, so I felt like Iaposd gone from my highest point to my lowest really. I posted my story online because when I was diagnosed I was going to tell my close friends and I thought people were going to hear about it anyway and when people hear that someoneaposs got cancer, you donapost want them to think the worst. I wanted people to know that this is a treatable type of cancer and I just thought that it wasnapost something that I wanted to hide, or be embarrassed about, itaposs just something thataposs happened. So I just wanted to share my journey and be open about it. I didnapost realise that Lymphoma is the most common cancer in teenagers and young adults and considering Iaposve never heard about the symptoms, I wanted to raise a bit of awareness in the process. I just wanted to show that you are still you as well when you are going through your treatment, youaposre not defined by a diagnosis. I didnapost want anyone to feel sorry for me, I wanted people to see that Iaposm still me. My diagnosis has put things in perspective - leaposs too short, just do what makes you happy I suppose. Zaraaposs dad, Lloyd Barton, is running the Brighton Marathon this April and is fundraising for the Teenage Cancer Trust, a charity that has been supporting her throughout her treatment.You can donate to Zaraaposs fatheraposs fundraising page hereRead MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON CharitiesEducationHospitalsTeenagersFluCancerFertilityHodgkins lymphoma" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: toyboys secret marriage 91 year
story: Toyboys secret marriage to -year-old woman sees grieving family lose £,Joan Blasss son and daughter became worried when a man  years younger became fiends with her and moved in with her five months before her deathJoan Blass died in March  at the age of  Image: Glen Minikin Daily MailByLucy MarshallGraeme Murray:,  Mar |commentsA toyboyaposs secret marriage to a -year-old bride seen a family lose £,. Joan Blass died in March , sparking the beginning of a nightmare for her family. Her son and daughter became worried when a man  years younger became friends with her and moved in with her five months before her death. Daughter Daphne Franks, of Skipton, North Yorkshire was concerned because her mum was not aware he lived in her home and did not no know his name or where he was from.She told LeedsLive : Mum never seemed to know he lived there.She was asking, aposwhat is his name  Where did he come from apos At this stage, Joan could barely recall her own name, let alone that of her new toyboy.  When she died, the family discovered that Mr Folan had married her and the dementia sufferer was still wearing the wedding ring from her late husband Ron. Ron died in  after  years of the couple being together. Her new marriage meant her two children Daphne,  ,and Michael, , lost out on their £, inheritance because the registry office ceremony annulled her will. Daphne discovered three days after her motheraposs death that she had been married in a civil ceremony at Leeds Town Hall. Speaking to Predatory Marriage UK, Daphne said: We had contacted my motheraposs GP on so many occasions, the police, the social services, and had also taken legal advice and had been told that she could not make another will or marry again because of her severe dementia. Taking the toyboy to court The marriage meant the will Mrs Blass had drawn up, naming her two children as beneficiaries, was void and she died intestate, meaning her new husband automatically inherited her assets. Daphne decided to take legal action after Folan, now , took over the funeral arrangements. The hearing lasted four days but sadly for the family, siding with Mr Folan. Mrs Franks and her relatives were left with a £, legal bill. On top of that, none of Joanaposs relatives were invited to her funeral and she was buried in an unmarked grave.  Pushing for change Since the nightmare the family have been pushing for action to stop predatory marriages. Predatory Marriage UK aims to reform marriage laws and procedures to protect people with dementia. In  Fabian Hamilton, MP for Leeds North East, called on the PM to stop elderly and vulnerable people being preyed upon by tricksters leading to families losing their inheritance. Mr Hamilton first began campaigning on the matter a few years ago after hearing a story he could “hardly believe was possible in modern Britain”. He said: “It’s not good enough for a registrar simply to say that because one of the participants in the marriage ceremony was smiling at the time, that meant consent was happily given. The family have been working with Hourglass charity to welcome round-the-clock help. Mrs Franks said a   helpline would make an absolute dference. The Frank family have recently been working with Hourglass charity to get round-the-clock help for those affected by elder abuse. Ms Franks said a   helpline would make an absolute dference. She added thatshe had known about a helpline before she would have definitely rung it. The Hourglass charity said it was moving Its helpline to a   operation because more than a quarter of the calls it received went unanswered during out of hours. It said Home Office funding meant it was now able to extend its service to make sure calls were being answered day and night. Richard Robinson, Hourglass CEO, said: Thankfully we are increasingly aware of other forms of abuse like child abuse and domestic violence, but the abuse of older people remains in the shadows even though it affects millions. So many people are suffering and donapost know where to turn for help. title: uk weather forecast brits bask
story: UK weather forecast: Brits to bask in balmy C to start week of scorching temperaturesThe Met Office has predicted "seven days at least" of "warm sunshine" with temperatures rising to C on Tuesday. People are being warned to wear sunscreenoutside for long periodsThe mercury could rise to C on Tuesday Image: Adam Gerrard   Daily MirrorByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsBrits can look forward to soaring temperatures over the next week with seven days at least of warm sunshine with the mercury set to hit C.Spring has arrived in the UK with above average temperatures on the back of a cold start to March, says the Met Office, although there will still be frosty starts to the day.People are set to head out this week and enjoy the sunshine with blue skies up and down the country. A high pressure system to the east of the country is moving in and by Wednesday it will be centred over the UK. Southern areas including parts of London and Cambridge are set to bask in up to C heat on Tuesday, and forecasters have advised anyone spending long periods outdoors to wear sunscreen.  Following a warm weekend when the mercury hit .C in Kinlochewe in Scotland, Met Office forecaster Aidan McGivern said Brits can look forward to a further “seven days” of sunshine “at least”. “There will be more spring sunshine to come during the rest of the week,” he said. “High pressure close to the east then becomes increasingly centred over the UK from Wednesday into Thursday and Friday. “That high pressure isn’t going anywhere for the foreseeable. For the next seven days at least it’s going to bring plenty of warm sunshine.”  He added that “iable amounts of cloud” will move across parts of northern England, the Midlands and southern Scotland on Tuesday bringing “a few lights showers”, but most of the day will be dry and sunny. Mornings will also feel cold and could drop to -C in Scotland but for the rest of the country it should be above freezing. A fresh start or a chilly start in places on Tuesday morning, you’ll see that cloud across central areas moving south and a few spots of rain associated with it but it tends to fizzle away by the afternoon perhaps reforming to give a few showers across northern England and southern Scotland later in the day, said Mr McGivern.  Otherwise away from that area, plenty of sunshine and in western parts, a sunnier day compared to Monday. Temperatures reaching C to C quite widely from central Scotland down to the south of England. Could see C to C in London or Cambridge, for example. The far north, Shetland, staying cold with a brisk breeze coming off the North Sea but for most the temperatures are well above average for the time of year. Similar temperatures are forecast for the following days, with the mercury dropping one or two degrees towards the end of the week. UK forecast for the next  days Tuesday sunny and warm for many, only very isolated showers. Today: Mostly dry with spells of hazy sunshine. Scattered showers may develop over the Midlands, northern England, southern Scotland and Northern Ireland during the afternoon. Most places missing these but the odd one could be heavy. Warm in the sunshine. Tonight: Any showers fading, then dry with clear spells. Some rural spots ending up with grass frost, while a few fog patches are likely, more especially in east and northeast England. Wednesday: After any fog clears, many areas fine, with temperatures well above average and feeling warm in the sunshine. One or two places in the east could catch a stray shower. Outlook for Thursday to Saturday: Dry for most with warm sunny spells and patchy rural frost and fog overnight. Cloudier across the far north with some patchy rain or drizzle at times. Light winds. title: you covid cold hay fever
story: Do you have Covid, a cold or hay fever  Experts share how to tell symptoms apartWith symptoms of Covid-, the common cold and hay fever overlapping, it can be hard to tell which youve got. Here health experts explain how to tell the dferenceIt can be hard to know whether you have Covid, a common cold or hay fever Image: Getty ImagesByAriane Sohrabi-ShirazSEO Editor:,  Mar |commentsCovid cases are rising in the UK, and with free lateral flow tests being scrapped from April , itaposll be harder to knowyou have the virusyou donapost have the usual symptoms. Although Covid cases are surging, there are also other seasonal illnesses around which could cause you to experience similar symptoms, such as the common cold and flu. And now spring has officially sprung, hay fever is being thrown into the mix. Itaposs estimated that almost half of the UKsuffer from hay fever, according to AllergyUK, but with overlapping symptoms it becomes hard to dferentiate between a common cold or even Covid-. Here, with the help of health experts, we explain the dference in symptoms, and what you should look out for. How to tellyouaposve got a cold or Covid  With so many overlapping symptoms, it can be hard to dferentiate between a cold and Covid.Firstly, be aware of the main symptoms of Covid. According to the NHS, they are: A high temperature A new, continuous cough A loss or change to your sense of smell or tasteThe common cold can have similar symptoms. According to the NHS, they are:A blocked or runny noseA sore throat Headaches Muscle aches Coughs Sneezing A raised temperature Pressure in your ears and face Loss of taste and smellDeep Patel, LloydsPharmacy’s Vaccination Services Manager, further explained the dference between a cold and Covid. He said: People can confuse a common cold and Covid- as they’re both respiratory illnesses, but they are caused by dferent viruses. Colds generally do not cause serious health problems such as pneumonia or bacterial infections, and they rarely lead to hospital care. Typical cold symptoms are sneezing a lot and a runny nose, sometimes you’ll also have a high temperature of .C or more. Unlike a cold the symptoms we see with Covid- tend to be much more severe and often include a dry and continuous cough, loss of taste and shortness of breath. You’re also more likely to have a fever with Covid- than with a cold but symptoms y for people infected with the corona virus. If you think you have symptoms of Covid- we recommend you take a lateral flow test as soon as possible.” Whataposs the dference between hay fever and Covid   Hay ever is usually worse between late March and September, especially when itaposs warm. According to the NHS, the main symptoms, similar to a cold and Covid, are:Sneezing and coughing A runny or blocked nose Itchy, red or watery eyes Itchy throat, mouth, nose and ears Loss of smell Pain around your temples and forehead Headache Earache Feeling tiredHighlighting the dference between hay fever and Covid, Dr Belinda Grfiths from The Fleet Street Clinic in London, said: Hay fever is an allergic condition which predominantly affects the nose and eyes. Common symptoms include itchy, red, watering eyes, sneezing and a running nose, which may feel blocked. In the majority of cases, excluding asymptomatic cases, Covid- tends to make you feel unwell. The most common symptoms remain to be a new continuous cough, loss of sense of taste and smell and a high-temperature. It is possible for the symptoms of both to overlap. For example, you can have a postnasal drip with hay fever, which can make you cough, but in general, the symptoms of hay fever tend to be milder than that of Covid. If the symptoms improve with an antihistamine or a nasal spray, it is likely to be hay fever. If they don’t improve it may be worse considering the symptoms are something . If you are not sure, or you have a temperature, loss of sense of smell and taste, a cough and general malaise, always check with your GP or call . You can take a rt-PCR test to exclude Covid-. How to find outyou have a cold, hay fever or Covid  The only way to know for sureyou have Covid is to do a test. At the moment the advice stands thatyou have Covid symptoms you shoulder order a free PCR test from the government website. You should do thisyou have any of the main symptoms of Covid. From April PCR tests will no longer be available, except for a small number of at-risk groups. More details of this will be announced in due course. news weird-news -something-woman-shares-how-"TikTok user shares concealer hack for an instant face ltByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Mar |commentsGetting older is inevitable, but there are things you can do to fake the appearance of a more youthful completion . Whilst good skincare plays a part in looking young in the long run, you can shave years off your face in just a few seconds using makeup.Suzi Strover is a -something woman who shares beauty tips on her TikTok account @skincaresuzi, like where to place blush, how to get more out of your bronzer and why you should be bending your mascara wand.But one of her videos, which promises to give you an instant facelt in just a few seconds, has gone viral, racking up more than . million views. Try this. Does it work for you  Suzi asks in the caption. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. She then asks in the on-screen text, Have you tried this as an instant facelt  In the clip, Suzi demonstrates the hack on one side of her face so that viewers can see the dramatic dference it makes. She begins by applying a combination of a creamy concealer and highlighter in thin lines around her face in an upwards, diagonal direction. The first line starts at the corner of her mouth, the second from the side of her nostril and the final one by her eye. She then uses a large brush to blend it all out in a circular motion. Once itaposs all buffed out, the dference is clearly visible. The side of her face with the makeup looksitaposs been pulled back.Since being posted, the video has racked up almost , likes and , comments from viewers who were impressed with the concept. One person said: The men must not find out we can shapesht. Another asked: What witchcraft is this  Wait! WHAT  commented a third. After trying it themselves, one person reported back saying: I tried it. It worked. Loved it. While someone  said: The best facelt is a smile. This comes as a mum-of-three revealed that not washing her face every day has helped her maintain her youthful glow and age-defying looks. Brenda Gabriel gives her face a wash just twice a week and instead of traditional water-based treatments, she does oil cleansing. Iaposm actually a little bit like Cameron Diaz because I donapost wash my face every day, she said, as you get older, it tends to dry out a little bit more, so now what I do is oil cleansing. And as for the claim that excess oil on the face causes breakouts, Brenda said: “It’s a total lie, especially when you’re getting older. It’s one of the best things to clean your face with. She also believes that meditation, a protein-rich diet and regular exercise has played a big part in keeping her looking young.Take a look at her advice, here. Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: crumpets cause debate no one
story: Crumpets cause debate as no one can agree on what theyre actually calledA heated debate has been sparked online over the humble crumpet as people from around the world have shared the dferent names they call them - and no one can agree on the correct oneWhat do you call these Image: Getty ImagesByCourtney PochinSenior Audience Writer:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsWhen it comes to crumpets, the only conversation we usually have about them is what topping to slather on when theyaposre fresh out of the toaster - do you go for a simple spread of butter or get a bit more creative But it seems thereaposs a lot more to be said about the small bread, as a recent debate on Twitter has shown. A social media user named Phil Sledge has caused a stir after sharing a snap of two buttered crumpets online and asking: What are these called where you live  Thousands of people have liked the tweet, with hundreds replying - and it seems many arenapost able to agree on the name for the savoury snack.Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter here.Some people were adamant they were crumpets while others called them pikelets and some thought they were English muffins. The official Deliveroo Twitter replied to Philaposs post, writing: Itaposs crumpets and any other answer is just plain wrong. Thanks for coming to our TED talk. While Heinz wrote: We call them circles of joy. Another posted: I call them crumpets but my we calls them pikelets. We were brought up in villages less than tree miles apart so Iaposve no idea why she calls them by the wrong name. Someone  said: Those are English Muffins here in Canada. I like mine toasted, buttered and covered in homemade preserves. A dferent user admitted: I always knew them as pikelets until fairly recently when they arrived in the supermarkets as crumpets. Either way, they are good with lots of butter and sometimes Marmite as well. In an attempt to clear some of the confusion, a former bakery worker explained why some people might call them pikelets, sharing a photo of a spikey tool used in baking. They added: That was my first job at a bakery... putting the holes in crumpets. We used a special tool called a apospikeletapos hence the confusion. I later progressed to the more specialised job of putting the hole in doughnuts, for which I used a larger tool called a aposdunkerapos.What do you call them  Let us know in the comments below.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON FoodViral" data-immediate"data-immediate"Serve the food you really want to eat by signing up for our tips and recipes and never be bored by your cooking againSign UpInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: grandad 38 1500 tattoos 98
story: Grandad, , has , tattoos on % of his body including his eyeballs and gumsMarcelo Bboy, , has more than , tattoos across almost his entire body with plans to add more to his leg and "private area" which are not yet covered in inkMarcelo has several modications, including black eye balls and teeth replaced with nickel ones Image: mediadrumworld @marcelobboyByAntony ThrowerNews ReporterJosie Adnitt:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A grandad says he has spent nearly £, getting tattoos all over his body, including his eyeballs.Model Marcelo Bboy, , , got his first aged  and since then has added around , across his entire body.As well as turning himself into an artwork, he has also had a number of body modications including having his tongue split in half to resemble a snake’s and replacing all of his teeth with nickel ones.The tattoos which garner the most attention however is the black ink he has added to his eyes and gums. Marcelo, from Bocaiuva, Brazil, said: Today, people look at me with curiosity and interest. I donapost hear many bad comments about how I look.Women are very enchanted by my tattoos and modications and I like all of my tattoos - there isnapost one that I could say was my favourite.My kids are totally cool with my tattoos and my daughter already has some of her own. Iaposm supportive of whatever they do. “The eyes are the modication that is most popular with people because many people are curious about how to get their eyes tattooed and have questions about the risk of going blind. I wasnapost worried about going blind because I understand the process - the eye pigmentation is only done in the white part of the eye. I have about % of my body tattooed and I think I have spent around ,in expenses on tattoos and body modications.” Marcelo, who has two children and one grandchild, now works as an artistic model and actor, as well as attending tattoo events as a public figure.  His most recent operation was inserting implants which are inserted under the skin for decorative purposes in his left arm. Marcelo has no plans on slowing down however as he has more he wants done after he has filled the last remaining areas on his body not covered with ink. He added: I only have a few spaces left without tattoos like intimate areas and some small spaces on my leg, but I plan to get them tattooed soon too. I was twenty-two when I realised I wanted more tattoos, and since then I have covered myself in them.  The advice I would give to those who want a lot of tattoos is to know exactly what they want and to work in the tattoo industry.”Earlier this week dad Karac Smith, , revealed how he has no problem getting a job despite being entirely covered in £, worth oftattoos , including all over hisface .He said that his extreme body inking actually helps him find employment, once even getting seven job offers in a week. The married dad-of-four, from Sheffield, got his first tattoo when he was  and has been employed ever since. He estimates that  percent of his body is now covered in tattoos, with only his cheeks and nose untouched from the ink machine. I always get comments like aposI bet you canapost find a jobapos but Iaposve never been out of work. title: man applauded brutally honest list
story: Man applauded for brutally honest list of housemate demands - including no eye contactA man who took to Facebook in search of a housemate has gone viral for his list of demands, which included someone who keeps to themselves and avoids "boring polite casual conversations”He posted the ad on Facebook Image: Getty Images MaskotByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Mar |commentsAn Australian man has been applauded for his honest housemate advert, which demanded no eye contact or boring conversations.The man posted the ad in the Perth Buy And Sell Western Australia Facebook group, where he admitted the only reason he had made the decision to rent out a roomwas so that he could save for a motorbike.He then went on to list the traits he was looking for in a potential housemate. These included someone who smokes outside, no paedophiles and a preferably introverted roommate who largely kept to themselves. However, he would consider computer hackers and people who are in and out of the country on work trips. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here.I really really don’t want a housemate, especially someone who talks too much or who has lots of visitors, he wrote, according to news.au.Prefer someone who just wants to use the room to set up a lan for computer hacking - or FIFO workers  . No eye contact or boring ‘polite’ casual conversations. They also shouldnapost have too many visitors popping in and out, the man wrote.The successful candidate, or should we say housemate, would be paying a week for a large room  minutes away from the city with high ceilings, internet and access to a large garden with a lemon and orange tree. They could also choose whether to receive the room furnished or unfurnished. Despite the large list of demands, Facebook users found the post refreshingly honest and praised him for his transparency. Best room to rent ad ever. Expectations and boundaries laid up front, one woman wrote. This comes as a nanny shares the bonkers list of responsibilities she was handed at a job interview. Hollis Jane Andrews, who now works as an actor, says she was considered for the role with a family in  and shared the two sheets of requirements set out on yellow paper she would have been expected to follow. The intense routine demanded the children were never unhappy or bored, and that she would also have to aposmagically transformapos into a cleaning machine while they napped and complete a  step bullet point list of jobs before they woke up.Take a look at the list here. Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: my cousin went travelling never
story: My cousin went travelling and we never heard from him again - its been  yearsAn anonymous woman has taken to Mumsnet to share a mysterious family story about her cousin, who she claims was never seen or heard from again after he went travelling  years agoHe was said to be travelling to AmericaImage: Getty ImagesByCourtney PochinSenior Audience Writer:,  Mar |comments A woman has captured the attention of Mumsnet users after sharing a mysterious tale about her cousin - and how he seemingly vanished into thin air. The unnamed mum took to the parenting forum to share the story and askpeople thought there was something she didnapost know.In her post, she claimed that her cousin was raised by her grandparents and when he was in his s, he decided he wanted to go travelling in America. She told how she was eight at the time, but remembers her grandparents helped him get some money together and he left, saying heaposd be back soon. However, he never ed from his trip - and he never wrote or called again either.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter here.Nobody ever heard from him again, she wrote. It broke my grandparentsapos hearts and they spent their final years worrying about him and whether he was OK. None of his friends ever heard from him again either. He completely disappeared off the face of the earth and there was no trace of him online .It has been  years since he vanished now.Last year I signed up to Ancestry and was looking at the family tree. I stumbled across something, I canapost remember what exactly it was now, but it showed that hehad an account and had recently been on there either researching the family or adding something to the tree.I sent him a message through the site asking how he was and telling him a bit about my le, how Iaposve had children etc. I gave my email address and said he could contact mehe wanted to be in touch.I didnapost hear anything back.  The woman goes on to share how she doesnapost understand why someone would want to disappear and never speak to their family again.I was only a child when he left but I remember having a lovely relationship with him and seeing him as something of a big brother. He obviously wants to be left alone which is his right but itaposs so confusing.Do you think thereaposs something I donapost know  More than  people have since replied to the post, with many sharing their thoughts on the situation.One person wrote: I think thereaposs probably a lot of things you donapost know and never will. I would leave him be. Another said: We can’t possibly know what went on any more than you. But it sounds like he’s made his choice to separate from his family and that should be respected. A third replied: He probably struggled with being rejected by his parents and wanted a new le. Too upsetting for him to face his family  I’m guessing you were raised by your parents  Maybe he found that hard to cope with- the unfairness. While someone  asked: How much of this did you hear see with your own eyes and ears, and how much did your GP tell everyone once he’d gone If he had a leaving party with his friends and wider family, oryou all went to wave him off from Heathrow, orhe spent ages telling everyone about his plan to hitchhike Route , or anything like that, ok, weird he changed his mind and never came back.If you only found out about this apostravellingapos plan after he’d gone, it’s honestly more likely there was some falling out you weren’t aware of and he just went no contact And your family claimed he’d gone travelling to explain it away to everyone, presumably expecting him to . Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. news weird-news teen-mobility-scooter-filmed-towing-"Wales: Mobility scooter driver spotted towing caravanByAntony ThrowerNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments A teenager had drivers in hysterics when he was spotted casually riding a mobility scooter on a road pulling a caravan behind him. The mystery driver was seen crossing a junction in front of other cars as he towed the portable home in his wake. The bizarre scene was filmed by Casey Hulme in north Wales, who joked on Facebook : “I can’t believe what I’ve just witnessed.“Only in Rhyl.” Her video has since been viewed .million times and had , shares by incredulous people.Casey, , told Mail Online : “I was on my way home with my friend and I saw the boy on the mobility scooter trying to pull out of a junction.“aposI turned the car around and we parked on a street off the main road the guy was going down with the caravan and watched them go past.aposI think my reaction on the video speaks for itself. We were crying with laughter.apos Thousands of people have commented on her original post. One said: “This will be me with the BMWthese prices keep on going up.” Another joked: “This is what happens when you expect to go away for a weekend and you donapost want to take the car because of the fuel prices.” Another said: “I really need to know how this ended. “I mean heaposs going to stop - but that caravan isn’t.”  The Government’s website says drivers do not need a licence for a mobility scooter but only certain types can be driven on roads. It is not the first time mobility scooters have been seen holding up traffic. Last year in Manchester a rider held up “more than  cars” by refusing to pull over in a one-way street as he waited for his chippy tea to be brought out, prompting honks from “irate” motorists.Bizarre footage of the incident shows the hungry customer parked up in the centre of the road in Manchester city centre last Friday, blocking a large truck and the cars behind from passing. Multiple people were seen attempting to help or intervene, only for the stubborn man to repeatedly shout “I just want the fish and chips that Iaposve paid for”. Passerby David Williams had presumed the battery on the manaposs scooter was flat so went over to seehe could help but was told to “back off” by the scooter user.Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON VehiclesMobility scooterTeenagers" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: woman told job interview fantastic
story: Woman told job interview was fantastic - but is rejected due to strong Welsh accentA woman has shared a rejection email she received following a job interview in which shes told recruiters thought she was fantastic but she wasnt being hired due to her strong Welsh accentEluneds tweet has gone viral Image: Eluned Anderson Media WalesByCourtney PochinSenior Audience Writer:,  Mar |commentsNo form of rejection is ever easy to take, but some are certainly more dficult to handle than others. And one woman has had peopleaposs jaws dropping as she shared a look at a rejection email she was sent following a recent job interview.Eluned Anderson from Cardf took to social media to share a screenshot of the email in which she was told that recruiters at the company thought she was fantastic.They go on to say that she performed very well and that her skillset would reflect well in the role. However, things take a turn as you keep reading, as they ultimately decide not to offer Eluned the position due to her strong Welsh accent and regional activities. Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter here.Alongside the email, the -year-old who is a regional ambassador for Holocaust UK, wrote: First time Iaposve ever been told Iaposve got a strong Welsh accent, so I suppose thataposs a win  The full email reads: Hi Ellie, Thank you so much for your time in applying for the role of [job title removed] and attending the interview at such short notice. We thought you were fantastic and performed well throughout. Your skillset would reflect well in the role. Iaposm sorry to say, however, that we have decided not to proceed with your application. It was decided that your strong Welsh accent, accompanied by your regional activities, would not suit the office environment. Thanks once again for your interest and time. Thousands of people have liked, shared and replied to the tweet, with many pointing out that Eluned is being discriminated against.Under the Equality Act , it is against the law to discriminate against anyone because of their race, including colour, nationality, ethnic or national origin.One person said: I think youaposll find that reply furnishes you with a strong claim for employment discrimination. Seriously - take advice. Another wrote: I am sorry what      This is WILDLY not okay ! A third responded: If theyaposre doing that, what  are they discriminating against  Iaposm stunned. This is horrible and definitely discrimination under the Equality Act, added Deeba Syed, an employment lawyer, who went on to offer a chat. Similarly, Jamie Hanley of Trade Union Law offered to have his team take a look at the matter on behalf of Eluned.Do you have a story to share  We pay for stories. title: 16 critics vladimir putin who
story: critics of Vladimir Putin who died violently or in suspicious waysA number of high profile critics of Vladimir Putin have died in violent or mysterious circumstances. This includes Alexander Litvinenko, who was poisoned in London after drinking a laced cup of teaHis government salary is just ,ByRosaleen FentonDeputy Features Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA number of high profile critics of Putin and his policies have ended up murdered over the years Famously, the murder of Alexander Litvinenko occurred on British soil - after the former spy died from poisoning after drinking a laced cup of tea. Here are some of the other people who openly criticised Putin — a former lieutenant colonel of the KGB, and ex-head of the FSB — before they died.It comes as Ukrainian officials claim they have discovered a plot to poison Putin - and that a successor has already been chosen, as sanctions continue to cripple the Russian economy.In , it was reported that US and UK authorities were revisiting ious suspicious deaths of Russian citizens abroad. The trail of mysterious deaths, all of which happened to people who possessed information that the Kremlin did not want to be made public, should not be ignored by western countries, the Senate foreign relations committee warned that year.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here Alexander LitvinenkoFormer KGB agent Alexander Litvinenko, a Russian defector, was poisoned with radioactive polonium- in London. He died three weeks after drinking a cup of tea laced with the deadly substance. After leaving the FSB, which was run by Putin, he openly criticised the agency and accused of it carrying out a series of apartment bombings in  that left hundreds dead. He also accused Putin of ordering the murder of Anna Politkovskaya - a Russian journalist The official report into the death found that he was poisoned by Russian agents Andrei Lugovoi and Dmitry Kovtun, and concluded that the order to assassinate Litvinenko was aposprobablyapos given by Putin himself. Russia refused to extradite them after it was requested they attend for questioning, and in , Lugovoi was granted a medal for services to the motherland.Anna Politkovskaya  Anna Politkovskaya was a Russian journalist, who accused the President of turning the country into a police state in her book aposPutinaposs Russiaapos. She covered abuse in Chechnya and was an outspoken critic of Putinaposs. She was murdered by contract killers who shot her at point-blank range in a lt in her building in . Five men were convicted of her murder, but the judge ruled that it was a contract killing, with £,paid by a person unknown.Putin denied any Kremlin involvement in her death, saying that her death in itself is more damaging to the current authorities both in Russia and the Chechen Republic ... than her activities.Denis Voronenkov Former Russian MP Denis Voronenkov, who had fled to Ukraine, was shot dead in Kiev just before he was about to testy against the pro-Putin Prime Minister of RussiaDenis Voronenkov, , a former Communist Party MP in Russiaaposs State Duma, was shot three times by an unidentied gunman outside the Premier Palace, a luxury hotel in . Previously loyal to the Kremlin, Voronenkov and his we Maria Maksakova, who is also a former MP, became critical of Putinaposs rule. In an interview, he likened modern-day Russia to Nazi Germany and said its annexation of Crimea from Ukraine in  was illegal. He told that he and his we, along with their young son Ivan had left Russia because he was being followed by the security services. We need to be careful, he said. We are poking a sore spot of the Kremlin with our statements. Ukraineaposs Prosecutor General Yuriy Lutsenko said his murder was a contract killing, but no one has ever been prosecuted.The attacker and Mr Voronenkovaposs bodyguard were both injured in an exchange of fire and taken to hospital. The killer later died, police said.President Poroshenko, the Ukrainian President of the time, accused Russia of carrying out the murder in order to silence a man who was forced to leave [Moscow] for political reasons. He said: Once again we have witnessed a textbook method of the Russian special forces, which we have repeatedly seen in ious European capitals. Mikhail Lesin  Former Russian press minister Mikhail Lesin was found beaten to death in a Washington hotel room in . A report confirmed that Lesin, who created Russia Todaydied of blunt force trauma to the head. It was reported that he was considering making a deal with the FBI before his death, in order to avoid corruption charges. The former government minister was previously at the heart of Russiaaposs political circle and would have been privy to a lot of inner deals and ongoings. He was once press minister to Mr Putin during his first term, before being dismissed and moving to the US. In an article about his death, BuzzFeed quoted an FBI agent who said: Lesin was beaten to death. There seems to be an effort here to cover up that fact for reasons I canapost get into. Boris Nemtsov  Boris Nemtsov, the leader of the Russian opposition was shot dead in front of the Kremlin seven years ago. Nemtsov, then one of Russiaaposs most outspoken critics of Putin, had at the time of his death been organising opposition rallies against Russiaaposs military involvement in Ukraine. He became deputy PM and was once touted as a possible presidential candidate - but it was Putin who took over from former president Boris Yeltsin in . Nemtsov supported the choice initially but became more outspoken as Putin rolled back civil liberties and he helped release several reports on official corruption. Just hours after protesting the war in Ukraine, he was shot by an unknown killer outside the Kremlin. Putin took personal control of the investigation, with critics dubbing it a cover-up Paul Klebnikov  Paul Klebnikov, a US investigative reporter and editor of Forbes Russia was shot dead outside his office in Moscow in  He had previously written about corruption in the country and investigated the ongoings of wealthy Russians, with Forbes publishing a list of the countryaposs richest people, Klebnikov was killed in a drive-by shooting in an apparent contract killing. Boris Berezovsky One of the countryaposs most powerful men, the self-made Russian oligarch helped Putin rise to power.  But the pair fell out, and he moved to London, where he became an outspoken critic of the President. He accused the Kremin of being behind Litvinenkoaposs death - before being found dead at his Berkshire home in . He was found dead in his bath in a locked bathroom with a noose around his neck. At an inquest into his death, a coroner ed an open verdict. Stanislav Markelov and Anastasia Baburova Leading human rights lawyer Stanislav Markelov was shot down by a masked gunman near the Kremlin in . He was well known for representing Chechen civilians who had suffered atrocities committed by the Russian military. On the day he died, in broad daylight, he had just held a conference protesting the release of an army colonel who had killed a young Chechen girl.He had also represented slain journalist Anna Politkovskaya. Journalist Anastasia Baburova, , was killed after trying to come to his assistance. Russian authorities said a neo-Nazi group was behind the murders, and two members were convicted. Sergei Magnitsky  Lawyer Sergei Magnitsky died in police custody in November  after being brutally beaten and denied medical care. He had been working for British-American businessman William Browder, to investigate tax fraud. When he allegedly found evidence suggesting police were behind the fraud, he was arrested and charged with having carried it out himself. in , three years after he died, he was convicted of tax fraud. Since then, Browder successfully lobbied the US government to impose sanctions on people linked to his death. Natalia Estemirova  The prominent human rights activist was abducted outside her home, in the Chechen capital, Grozny, and shot in . Her body was found in Ingushetia, to the west of Chechnya, and colleagues said she had been working on highly sensitive cases. The court ruled was no evidence of state involvement in her murder, while Russian officials claim that she was killed by an Islamist militant whose whereabouts are unknown. The -year-old had been collecting evidence of human rights abuses in Chechnya since the start of the second war there in . She had previously worked with Anna Politkovskaya. Sergei Yushenkov  Yushenkov co-founded the opposition Liberal Russia party with late businessman Boris Berezovsky before he was shot dead in Moscow in April , outside his apartment. Four men were convicted of his murder. As co-chairman, he fiercely criticised the Kremlin and a slew of anti-democratic legislation, as well as the governmentaposs wars in Chechnya. Yuri Shchekochikhin  Yuri Shchekochikhin, Anna Politkovskayaaposs editor at Novaya Gazeta, died in  after a mysterious -day illness. Official reports said he died of a aposrare allergic reactionapos, but nobody ever explained what Shchekochikhin was allergic to, and his family have previously said that they thought he was poisoned. He covered crime and corruption in the former Soviet Union and was investigating the  apartment bombings when he contracted a mysterious illness in July . His medical documents were deemed classied by Russian authorities. Yevgeny Khamaganov Yevgeny Khamaganov, the editor-in-chief of Asia-Russia Daily died in unexplained circumstances. The Index against Censorship reports: According to local media, Khamaganov was taken to hospital on  March because of his diabetes, fell into a coma and died several days later. Some reports cited speculation that he was instead hospitalised after being beaten by unknown assailants. Khamaganov was known for articles critical ofthe Russian federal government’s policies. Nikolai Andrushchenko Nikolai, who was known for his criticism of President Vladimir Putin died after being beaten by unknown attackers in .Two strangers approached him and demanded he hand over documents into his investigation on abuses of power by police officers. After the attack, he refused to report it to the police and was attacked a few days later. The journalist, , who co-founded the Novy Peterburg newspaper and made his name covering human rights and crimes, slipped into a coma and never regained consciousness. He died in hospital following brain surgery. At the time, the editor of Novy Peterburg, Denis Usov, linked the assault to articles it had published about corruption in the city.Nikolay Alekseevich Glushkov  The exiled Russian critic of Putin was strangled with a dog lead at his home in New Malden, South West London, in March  by a hitman who tried to make the attack look like suicide. He had told friends that heaposd survived an attempt to poison him previously.Yuli Dubov, the last surviving member of a group of Putin critics in the UK, exclusively spoke to the Mirror earlier this month.He said: All of the history of Nikolaiaposs communications with the outside world were on his laptop, his phone and his iPad. They have all been seized by the police and the man who killed Nikolai was certainly on them. Nikolai let his killer into his house and there is no way he would have done that without communicating with him first. I think the British police and security services know who did it, they just havenapost got enough evidence. I believe that whoever was responsible is back in Russia and we will never see them leave the country. Coroner Chinyere Inyama last year recorded a verdict of unlawful killing. title: family tiktok dancers share unusual
story: Family of TikTok dancers share the unusual names of their  kids while moonwalkingThe Storm family have been wowing TikTok audiences with their dance moves and recently revealed the names of each family member while showing off their moonwalkThe Storm family are known for their uplting dance challenges on TikTok Image: tiktok @mrsstormByLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments A family of TikTok dancers have revealed the names of their  children in a video showing off their moonwalk skills. The Storm family have captured the hearts of their almost , followers posting motivational dance challenge videos on TikTok since the pandemic.But their childrenaposs names get equal attention with all but one having uncommon monikers. The brood revealed their names in a recent clip where they took it in turns to perform the moonwalk. Mum Iris Purnell and her partner started the groove followed by teenagers Malikhai and Junior, both , Jahni, , and Trinity, . Next it was up to Messiah, , to give it a shot followed by JoJo, , Love, nine, and Seven, who coincidentally is currently seven years old.  The only sibling to have a more popular name is six-year-old Michael who then took the stage to show off his moonwalk moves. Five-year-old Royal and three-year-old Heavenly then showcased their moves followed by the familyaposs youngest member two-year-old Hope. Hundreds of viewers chimed in to give their views on who was the best moonwalker in the dancing challenge. Dad and the older boys killed it, one person said. Itaposs hard to pick. In my opinion I think everybody issss. Aye ayeeeeee, another wrote. Get it Dad, Seven and Love, a third commented.  Many fans were quick to praise Sevenaposs moves with his dadaposs moonwalk also proving popular among their followers. Two-year-old Hope, who was filmed walking backwards in her rendition of the moonwalk, was also a favourite. While many others were quick to praise the familyaposs positive energy. Gosh the smiles are awesome! Beautul family! one person said. I love your family so much, always put a big smile on my face amazing, another added. The family have so far racked up . million likes on their TikTok page where they regularly perform group dances in their mission tospread love and light through their talent. news world-news friends-beg-vladimir-putins-lover-"Tokyo : Alina Kabaeva slams judges over Averina decisionByDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsFriends of Vladimir Putinaposs alleged lover have begged her to go to Moscow and persuade him to end the war, it is claimed.Former gymnast Alina Kabaeva is believed to be holed up in a luxury mountain mansion in Switzerland as calls mount for her to be expelled.The -year-old, who is rumoured to have four children with the Russian President, is not among the figures close to Putin who are facing sanctions. Pals are said to be hopeful that Kabaeva can persuade him to bring the bloodshed to an end.A source told Page Six : “Alina’s female friends are begging her to fly to Putin and persuade him to end the war.“He doesn’t seem to be listening to anybody, but perhaps he might listen to her.” But the insider claimed Kabaeva is fearful about how Putin will reactshe voices any opposition to the conflict. They said that the president is surrounded by rings and rings of security, adding: Alina says she doesn’t knowshe can get to him – and evenshe does – she doesn’t knowshe’ll be able to get out again to be with their kids.” The West has so far not sanctioned Kabaeva - although as well as being Putin’s rumoured secret partner, she is also chairman of the board of directors at National Media Group, a major Kremlin-obedient TV and newspaper behemoth, at a salary of almost £ million a year. A petition signed by nearly , people likens her with Eva Braun, Hitleraposs mistress.It says: “It’s time you reunite Eva Braun with her Führer. And it continues: “Despite the current war, Switzerland continues to host an accomplice of Putin’s regime. “The public has just learned that the Russian political and media figure, and former [rhythmic gymnast], Alina Kabaeva, is hiding the consequences of the sanctions imposed on the Russian Federation in your country.“She is the favourite we of [the] delusional dictator and war criminal who has been treacherously attacking Ukraine over the past weeks. “As she is supportive of social activities in Russia, she has been attempting to get Russian citizens accustomed to the reality of sanctions after , and personally proclaimed: ‘The worse it gets, the better for us!’”The signatories question why “given the volume of sanctions placed on Russia” the authorities continue to host her and her family at a time when Putin “is destroying the lives of millions”. The petition continues: For the first time in modern history, your country has violated its neutrality, which it did not even do vis-à-vis Nazi Germany in the th century, and joined the sanctions against Putin and his surroundings. “And now you are allowing his favourite mistress and her children to hide within the borders of your state.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Eva BraunVladimir PutinRussia Ukraine war" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: hero dad smiles family moments
story: Hero dad smiles with family in last picture before he drowned saving kids on holidayBrad Colemans we Hulya had a heart attack due to stress as her husband saved their children Raiden and Aleyna from the sea off the coast of New South Wales, AustraliaBrad Coleman with his children, Aleyna and Raiden, and we Hulya not long before he died Image: GoFundmeByMilo BoydNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA dad was photographed smiling with his family before he drowned saving the le of his kids in what was nearly a double tragedy. Brad Coleman is seen in the snap, taken on March , with his we Hulya and his two children Raiden and Aleyna. At the time the family had just arrived on a holiday at Hyam’s Beach on the New South Wales south coast.Just a few short hours after the happy family photo was taken Raiden and Aleyna went swimming in the sea, News.au reports. Suddenly an unusually strong rip current began pulling them out into deeper water, causing the children to scream in terror. Brad rushed into the water and managed to swim through the water to both Raiden, , and Aleyna, , who he helped get to safety. Tragically the -year-old didnapost survive.  Hearing the commotion, Hulya rushed to the water where she started having a heart attack triggered by shock, GB reports. The mother-of-two had to be rushed to hospital for treatment. Days after she was released the family suffered another tragic loss when her father died. “This poor family from Sydney’s west has been through so much grief over the past few weeks and the future is going to be tough,” present Ben Fordham told listeners on GB. “They’re just really decent people who’ve experienced extraordinary tragedy. Everyone who knew Brad loved him dearly. He died a hero.”  Bradaposs death notice reads: “Cherished husband to Hulya. Much loved dad to Raiden  Aleyna. Treasured son to Susan  Greg. Adored brother to Steven  Scott. Brad was a loving grandson, nephew, cousin, brother-in-law  friend to many. So Close, No Matter How Far.” Relative Jen Couttas said that Brad was an exceptional person and that his death has completely rocked the family. The grieving relative said that Hulya has been left absolutely devastated by the death. A fundraiser has been set for the family, which has raised the equivalent of more than £,. On the pageaposs description family friends wrote that the Colemans were away for a much-needed break when tragedy struck.  “On that Friday afternoon, a rare long weekend getaway for the family, Brad’s children, aged  and , got into dficulty in the water, they recalled. “Brad, a devoted father, didn’t hesitate. A hero, he saved his children but unfortunately could not save himself. “Brad leaves behind his two children, Raiden and Aleyna, and we and soulmate, Hulya. His family must face a future without him, their lives changed in an instant in the most painful manner. “Brad was my brother, my best friend, and the best man I knew. On behalf of my family, I am setting up this GoFundMe to support Hulya and the children. It is open to anyone who can contribute.” To view the fundraiser click here.
